intro: Sageretia hamosa, commonly known as the Mexican wild quinine, is a shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes coffee and gardenias, and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that are typically clustered in cymes. Its fruits are follicles that release tiny, wind-dispersed seeds. Sageretia hamosa is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and along streambanks.
